question: Following blunt trauma a young male presents with a D shaped pupil. What is the diagnosis?
exp: Iridodialysis, in which the iris is torn away from its ciliary attachment for a variable distance, occurs more frequently. A black biconvex area is seen at the periphery, and the pupillary edge bulges slightly inwards forming a 'D'-shaped pupil. In a blunt trauma, substance of the iris is often torn. The most common lesions are minute ruptures in the pupillary margin which are of little significance, while radiating lacerations of the iris, sometimes extending to the ciliary margin, are rare. Iridoschisis-This rare condition occurs most commonly as a degenerative ageing senile phenomenon, though it may follow as a late result of severe trauma. Large dehiscences appear on the anterior mesodermal layer of the iris and strands of this tissue may float into the anterior chamber.

question: Which of the following is an ine metal that can be left alone in eye?
exp: Lead is an ine material that can be left alone in eye without any intervention. Else all intraocular foreign bodies should ideally be removed surgically as the injury itself may induce damage as well as long term chemical toxicity INTRAOCULAR FOREIGN BODIES- They can be classified into the following types. 1) Frequently produce severe inflammatory reactions- Magnetic: Iron, steel, tin- Non - magnetic: Copper and vegetable matter- Typically produce mild inflammatory reactions- Magnetic: Nickel- Nonmagnetic: Aluminium, mercury, zinc, vegetable matter. 2). question: Which of the following is not an indication of immediate treatment in cases of trauma
exp: Hyphaema is not an indication of immediate treatment, most of the times it resolves on its own Remember Hyphaema in blunt trauma resolves mostly with time, indication of immediate hyphaema drainage are *High IOP for many days on persistent medication (IOP > 25 on MMT for 5 days, > 50 for more than 2 days) *Corneal blood staining *Chances of recurrence high (Sickle cell anemia)

question: In a patient of head injury, who presents with headache and increased intracranial pressure, the effect on pupil is:
exp: Effect on pupil is ipsilateral mydriasis. - In this patient of head injury bleeding occurs, which increases Intra cranial pressure- This increased intra cranial pressure compresses and damages the 3rd nerve- 3rd nerve carry the parasympathetic fibers which is responsible for pupillary constriction- So, the unopposed sympathetic fibers mediated by the 5th nerve dilate the pupil - Hence patient comes with ipsilateral mydriasis Hutchinson's pupil is an ipsilateral mydriasis due to 3rd cranial nerve compression by an intracranial mass lesion including intracranial bleeds
